The model above is a simplified representation of the vehicle structure. It includes a single instance of each component type, which is a subclass of the `VehicleComponent` class. The `Vehicle` class is a composite component that contains a single instance of each of its subcomponents. The `Wheel` component is a subclass of `VehicleComponent` and is quantified with a `quantity` attribute to ensure that there are exactly four wheels in the vehicle. The `Engine

<SysML:System>
  <SysML:Component name="Vehicle">
    <SysML:Property name="Type">
      <SysML:Enum>
        <SysML:EnumValue name="Small"/>
        <SysML:EnumValue name="Large"/>
      </SysML:Enum>
    </SysML:Property>
    <SysML:Property name="EngineType">
      <SysML:Enum>
        <SysML:EnumValue name="SmallEngine"/>
        <SysML:EnumValue name="LargeEngine"/>
      </SysML:Enum>
    </SysML:Property>
    <SysML:Property name="EngineSpecification">
      <SysML:Property name="CylinderCount">
        <SysML:Constraint>
          <SysML:Value>4</SysML:Value>
        </SysML:Constraint>
      </SysML:Property>
    </SysML:Property>
  </SysML:Component

<System>
  <System.Interfaces>
    <Interface name="Engine">
      <Interface.Attributes>
        <Attribute name="type" value="small|large"/>
      </Interface.Attributes>
      <Interface.Members>
        <Member name="cylinders" type="Integer">
          <Member.Attributes>
            <Attribute name="min" value="4"/>
            <Attribute name="max" value="6"/>
          </Member.Attributes>
        </Member>
      </Interface.Members>
    </Interface>
  </System.Interfaces>
</System>

Input:
The system is required to classify and label each component to meet information security management requirements. Every component must be clearly assigned a security classification level, such as "Unclassified," "Confidential," or "Secret." When a component is marked as "Confidential," the system should be able to recognize and display its corresponding classification attribute, thereby enabling effective differentiation and protection of sensitive information during system operation and document management.

<Interaction> ::= <Kind> <Name>
<Kind> ::= 'Interaction' | 'Kind'

<system_transition_diagram>
  <system_state_node name="off">
    <transition name="VehicleStartSignal" target="starting"/>
  </system_state_node>
  <system_state_node name="starting">
    <transition name="VehicleOnSignal" target="on"/>
  </system_state_node>
  <system_state_node name="on">
    <transition name="VehicleOffSignal" target="off"/>
  </system_state_node>
</system_transition_diagram>
```

<system_behavior>
  <state_machine>
    <state id="shutdown">
      <transition onEvent="start_signal" to="startup"/>
      <transition onEvent="shutdown_signal" to="shutdown"/>
    </state>
    <state id="startup">
      <transition onEvent="start_signal" to="running"/>
      <transition onEvent="shutdown_signal" to="shutdown"/>
    </state>
    <state id="running">
      <transition onEvent="shutdown_signal" to="shutdown"/>
    </state>
  </state_machine>
</system_behavior>
The system shall be capable of managing the vehicleâ€™s start-up, operation, and shutdown processes. When the user issues a vehicle start signal while the vehicle is in the shutdown state, the vehicle should enter the start-up state. Upon receiving a vehicle started signal, the system shall set the vehicle status to running. If the user issues
```

  <SysML:Component name="QualityAggregationManagementSystem">
    <SysML:Attribute name="simpleMass" type="SysML:Mass"/>
    <SysML:Attribute name="totalMass" type="SysML:Mass"/>
    <SysML:Component name="SimpleThing">
      <SysML:Attribute name="totalMass" type="SysML:Mass" value="self.simpleMass"/>
    </SysML:Component>
    <SysML:Component name="CompositeThing">
      <SysML:Attribute name="totalMass" type="SysML:Mass" value="self.simpleMass + sum(subcomponent.totalMass)"/>
      <SysML:ComponentRef name="subcomponent" type="SysML:Component"/>

```
<SysML:System>
  <SysML:System.name>Systematic Risk Metadata Modeling and Management</SysML:System.name>
  <SysML:System.description>
    <SysML:Text>
      This system is designed for systematic risk metadata modeling and management across various scenarios, causes, and failures. Users can identify and describe different scenarios that may occur within the system. For each scenario, the specific causes and their probabilities of occurrence can be detailed, and possible failure types along with their severity levels can be associated. Furthermore, the system supports the description and tracking of causal relationships between scenarios, facilitating the understanding and analysis of risk propagation chains. On this basis, users can also combine a set of interrelated scenarios, causes, and failures to form complete risk scenarios, supporting risk analysis and decision-making. The system metadata is compatible with standard modeling languages, making it easy to integrate into larger systems engineering environments and enhancing the systematic capabilities of risk identification, analysis, and management.
</SysML:Text>
  </SysML:System.description>
  <SysML:System.scenarios>
    <Sys

<SysML:System>
  <SysML:Component name="Equipment">
    <SysML:Component name="Battery">
      <SysML:Property name="BatteryLevel" type="Real" unit="%">
        <SysML:Monitoring>
          <SysML:Monitoring name="MonitorBatteryLevel">
            <SysML:Condition name="BatteryAging">
              <SysML:Condition name="LowBatteryLevel">
                <SysML:Condition name="LowBatteryState">
                  <SysML:Condition name="DeviceShutdown">
                    <SysML:Severity level="High"/>
                  </SysML:Condition>
                </SysML:Condition>
              </SysML:Condition>
            </SysML:Condition>
          </SysML:Monitoring>
        </SysML:Property>
      </SysML:Component>
    </SysML:Component>
  </SysML:System>
```

The output model should be structured in a way that it can be used to create a SysMLâ€¯v2 textual code that represents the system architecture design. The model should include the following elements:

- A root component that represents the top-level of the system.
- A set of subsystems that are directly related to the root component.
- A set of components that are directly related to the subsystems.
- A set of safety-related components, marked with their safety attributes.
- A set of non-safety components.
- A hierarchy view that displays the components in a tree format.
- A safety view that displays the safety-related components along with their mandatory or optional status.
- A non-safety view that displays all non-safety components.
- A tabular representation of the system structure and safety features.

The output model should be structured in a way that it can be used to create a SysMLâ€¯v2 textual code that represents the system architecture design. The model should include the following elements:

- A root component that represents the top-level of the system.
- A set of subsystems that are directly related to the root component.
